title: Making publishing work for you
body:
In our first module we explored how to make transparency work for you through outlining the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. In this module we look at one of the biggest barriers to realising those benefits - inconsistent publishing approaches.

In this module you will learn:

  • The importance of ensuring the data you publish is clean and consistent
  • The 5 ways to decide where you should publish
  • The 3 steps to making sure users can find your data

This module also provides useful links out to supporting documents and services that can help save time in your publication.

title: Why does consistency matter?
body:
Open data needs to be simple for anyone to use, whether for a new app, a study or just to gain a deeper understanding of the subject.

The greatest use comes when the same type of data is consistent across different publishers. An application that tells you where local toilets are should be able to work everywhere, not just in one town. Consistancy is also important because it allows you to combine your data with that of other authorities for internal use.

For publishers in local authorities, making data available in a consistent format is the best way to make your open data useful both internally and to others.

title: Is the quality of my dataset suitable for publication?
displayTitle: Is the quality of my dataset suitable for publication?
body:
The better the quality of your datasets, the better the results from users. Unfortuntely, errors and inconsistancies will always occur in data. Common errors include duplicated entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes and different data formats. In the next section you can find out how to spot these errors in your own data.

Fortunately there are free, purpose-built cleaning tools designed to deal with messy data. We recommend OpenRefine which can help you quickly and securely clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can even automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets. Importantly, you can share your record of changes with everyone, including other staff, so that your colleagues can benefit from your cleaning.

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.

title: Common errors in data: A spotter's guide
displayTitle: Common errors in data: A spotter's guide
body: When looking at the quality of your own data, there are a number of common errors you should check for.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

An additional challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) format.

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything which is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body: Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1200000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2 which causes errors.

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data is sometimes measured in ranges, such as age or salary range. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to also run your data through a spell checker to catch errors.

title: How to publish your dataset: Choosing where to publish
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: Choosing where to publish
body: Your publishing location provides the gateway for access for your users. When choosing where to publish, start by thinking about how people will search and/or discover the data and consider carefully the following:

_items.title: 1. Pick a platform
_items.body: Platforms can simplify the process of publishing your data. You may already have a data or content publishing platform that is suitable for your needs. If so you can publish there. If you don't have a platform, you may want to consider some of the leading solutions used by other authorities such as CIPFA/Redbridge's Datashare, Swirrl's PublishMyData or CKAN to simplify the process of publishing.

_items.title: 2. Talk about data
_items.body: It is a good idea to publish data on your own website, giving it a home. Make a small section and navigation header that will help people discover data. Make sure the data section is visible from anywhere on your site.

_items.title: 3. Include links across your site
_items.body: Once the data has a home, people need to find it. It is unlikely that everyone will discover your data by browsing to it directly. Most of your users will search (using a search engine) and hit some page on your (or someone else's) website. It is important to include links to the data on all relevent pages where data has been used to help people navigate their way to the raw data.

_items.alt: Optimise your data for search engines
_items.title: 4. Optimise your data for search engines
_items.body: Most people today will use a search engine to look for data. Search engines need to be able to find all the relevant details about your datasets. It is important to include good metadata alongside your data and allow search engines to harvest this data and make it easy for people to find you this way.

_items.title: 5. Increase the number of links
_items.body: On the web, links are key. The more links you have, from more different sites, the easier your stuff will be to find. One way of achieving greater numbers of links is through cataloging your data in others catalogues, like data.gov.uk.

title: How to publish your dataset: Improving visibility
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: Improving visibility
instruction: Follow the steps below to make your open data easier for people to find and use.

_items.title: 1. Provide a consistent location
_items.body:
You should provide your data through a series of reliable and consistant web addresses (called Uniform Resource Identifiers or URIs). We reccomend using two URIs for any dataset you publish.

The primary URI should use the LGA's directory of common identifiers to refer to your local authority. You can use the LGA directory to look up the correct code for your authority in seconds.

The secondary URI should be more informative and point to the primary. For example, a dataset from Hampshire county council about senior salaries might be accessible from 'http://www3.hants.gov.uk/opendata/datasets/senior-salaries.htm'. This second URI lets anyone read what the dataset is before they navigate to it.

_items.alt: Register the dataset in a catalogue
_items.title: 2. Register the dataset in a catalogue
_items.body:
A catalogue is a collection of datasets published by different sources. There are two catalogues which it is important to add your authority's data to.

The first is data.gov.uk, the UK's national open data portal with a huge community of users, registration is simple and requires only key metadata information.

The second is LG Inform, the community resource for local authority data. Registration with LG Inform is automatic once you have an up-to-date inventory (see step 7)

_items.title: 3. Update your inventory
_items.body: The LGA inventory lets other people know what data you have published. The inventory encourages consistent referencing of datasets across councils to make it easier to find datasets on the same topic or in the same format. Your inventory entry can even be used to automatically update your datasets on data.gov.uk.

title: The benefits of publishing open data consistently - Local authority case studies
displayTitle: The benefits of publishing open data consistently - Local authority case studies
body: Local authorities have already seen benefits of following the consistent approaches above when publishing open data. The LGA keeps an extenisve collection of case studies that catalogue these impacts. Below are some examples of local authority benefits.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Learning from others: Barnet Council
_items.body: Barnet Council in north London is a diverse metropolitan authority. A relative latecomer to open data publishing, Barnet was able to benefit from the LGA's extensive case studies into open data publication to avoid some of the mistakes of early adopters. Using LGA, publishing guidelines, Barnet has now created a dedicated open data platform using Datapress. The platform currently hosts in excess of 180 datasets for the local area. Following LGA publishing guidelines helped Barnet save staff time and money by simplifying publishing processes. To discover more about Barnet's experience read their case study or visit their open data portal

_items.title: Building a simple data page: Wycombe District Council
_items.body: Wycombe council is an example of how to build a simple, informative open data page on your website. The page clearly displays the approriate licence, links to external guides and provides links to pages under well-described URIs that can be found by search engines. By following LGA guidance on their page, Wycombe has created a simple resource at a fraction of the cost of early adopters.

_items.title: Making it easy for users: North Somerset Council
_items.body: North Somerset Council used LGA guidance to publish more than 50 datasets in the Datashare platform. North Somerset's publication of clean, usable data in a single location enabled developer Eros Digital to produce the Discover North Somerset site. The website consumes a wide range of open data from tousist sites and transport links to events and hotels. The site now supports the local tourist economy, a key source of income for the area. The North Somerset example also demonstrates how publishing data based on demand from local people can create instant, tangible results.

title: Are you ready to publish open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to publish open data?

title: Choosing where to publish
body: Which of the following should you consider when choosing where to publish your dataset?

_items.text: Can my data be discovered from anywhere on my website?
How large will my data file be?
Is my metadata optimised for search engines?
Do I provide links to the data from wherever it is used?
Will my data make me look good to my boss?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Three essential considerations when choosing where to publish are whether people can find your data from anywhere, is your metadata friedly to search engines and whether you provide links to the data from wherever it is being used.

_incorrect.notFinal:
h5>Are you sure about that?

Three essential considerations when choosing where to publish are whether people can find your data from anywhere, is your metadata friedly to search engines and whether you provide links to the data from wherever it is being used.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Three essential considerations when choosing where to publish are whether people can find your data from anywhere, is your metadata friedly to search engines and whether you provide links to the data from wherever it is being used.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?
Three essential considerations when choosing where to publish are whether people can find your data from anywhere, is your metadata friedly to search engines and whether you provide links to the data from wherever it is being used.
_partlyCorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Three essential considerations when choosing where to publish are whether people can find your data from anywhere, is your metadata friedly to search engines and whether you provide links to the data from wherever it is being used.

title: Recognising errors in your data
body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean

_incorrect.notFinal:

title: Finding your data
body: When publishing your data, it is important to...

_items.text: use a consistent URI from the LGA directory
hide the location from the user

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

When publishing your data you should always use a consistent URI from the LGA's directory. You should also add a second URL which lets people know exactly what data they can expect to find on the page!

title: Make publishing work for you
body:
In this module we have explored how to publishing consistent, high-quality open data for your authority. Follow the guidance above and you will produce highly usable data which can generate signifiact impact for your authority as well as saving you time and money

In our next and final module, we will look at where you can find the best examples of authorities who have followed this guidance and see how their publication helped them acheive results.
